learning_outcomes.description: Understand fundamental principles of quantitative research.
Understand fundamental principles of qualitative research.
Understand the fundamental principles relating to ethical conduct of research.
Become familiar with research methodologies commonly used to investigate communication behaviour: surveys; experiments; content analysis; interviews; ethnographic observation.
Use research to find answers to real world problems.
Design a research project that addresses a specific research question.
Work collaboratively to communicate research findings.
Communicate about research to professional and lay audiences.

assessments.due_date: This assessment will take place in students regularly assigned tutorials from Week 5 to Week 12. Students will be assigned their presentation groups and presentation week at the beginning of the semester.
assessments.task_description:
Students will form small groups to deliver a short presentation and facilitate a class discussion relating to a course concept. Groups will be required to draw on course material and conduct their own research to inform their presentation and discussion. Tutorial presentations will happen at the beginning of tutorials and will last for approximately 15-20 minutes. Each group will be assigned a presentation week at the beginning of semester. This is a hurdle assessment and must be attempted to pass the course. If you fail to complete the tutorial presentation hurdle you will receive a (maximum) final grade of 3 for the entire course, regardless of performance in other assessment items.

Recording of Oral and Practical Assessment 

  • All presentations will be recorded for marking purposes via recording facilities available where the assessment takes place (eg. ECHO360, Zoom, camera device)  
  • Recordings will be retained by the School of Communication and Arts for at least 12 months from the release of the final grade for the course.  
  • Recordings will be stored in a secure manner and will only be accessed by authorised school staff for the purposes of: 
  • Moderation of marking;  
  • Provision of feedback to the student(s) recorded; and/or  
  • Re-marking following a successful re-mark application. 


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This assessment will take place in students regularly assigned tutorials. After completing the oral presentation, students will be required to upload their supplementary materials (i.e. power point files) to Black Board.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: Given that this is in-person group presentation there are no options for late submissions unless exceptional circumstances apply. All group members are required to attend and contribute to the presentation. If a group member is absent, the present group members will be instructed to continue the presentation and be graded as usual. The missing group member will receive an automatic 0 unless exceptional circumstances apply or their absence has been communicated and approved ahead of time by the course coordinator.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
The first written assessment is a reflective essay that requires students to critically consider the importance of ethics in research design. Students will be asked to consider the varied ethical challenges raised by up to two methods covered in weeks 1-5 of the course. Using previous studies, students will need to discuss the implications of these challenges and make suggestions for how they could be overcome in future research. Individual feedback from assessment will help guide assessment 3, the individual research proposal.


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The final assessment will require students to write a formal, individual research proposal. The proposal will require students to develop a problem statement and set of research questions. Students will need to outline:

  • A clear methodological approach and rationale
  • Ethical problems that may arise from their proposed project
  • The scale and feasibility of the proposed research


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2 Tutorial:

The tutorials will be conducted as workshops that include exercises designed to increase understanding and application of lecture content as well as aide with completion of assessment. Group work is an essential aspect of the course, so attending tutorials to work with your group is essential. Groups for upcoming assessment will be formed in this tutorial.


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L09
